body.section:
Every volunteer project gets its strength from its participants. We invite everybody interested to participate in Cayenne. If you are willing to help, this can be done in many different ways:
By contributing code.
By contributing documentation.
By testing Cayenne and reporting bugs.
By using Cayenne and reporting bugs.
By suggesting your own ideas on the mailing list and contributing code implementing them.
If you want to become a contributor, first you should probably subscribe to Cayenne Developer Mailing List. to see what issues are discussed and to communicate with the project team. Normally code and documentation contributions are made via patches sent to developer list. If your contributions are significant and you are willing to join the core team, current committers can vote to give you CVS write access and other committer rights.
http://sourceforge.net/cvs/?group_id=48132
Preferred way to create a patch is to check out Cayenne source tree via anonymous CVS, make changes to the local copy, and then run the following command (GUI CVS clients usually have support for this feature as well):
cd cayenne cvs diff -u > patch.txt
Resulting patch.txt file will contain changes to all Cayenne files as compared to the latest CVS version. Patches should be submitted via Cayenne Issue Tracker . There is no need to notify cayenne-devel mailing list, since all new issues are posted on this list automatically.
Anonymous CVS hosted by SourceForge.net has a few shorcomings. It is being built by synchronizing with master repository every once in a while, so there may be stale data in it. Also as of this writing (November 2003) anonymous CVS has been down most of the time. As an alternative you may use CVS snapshots of STABLE and HEAD brances taken at 6 hour intervals and available for download from http://objectstyle.org/downloads/cayenne/cvs-snapshots/ .
